Frank McCown wrote:
> Jigar Patel wrote:
>>
>> Hi,
>>
>> Does anyone have JAVA implementation [java file] of URL Normalization
>> [URL canonicalization]... Please provide i to me...
>> Or you can also provide where Heritrix does this normalization ?
>> [Crawlers usually perform some type of URL normalization in order to
>> avoid crawling the same resource more than once]
>> Thanks in advance...
>>
>> Regards,
>>
>> Jigar
>>
> 
> Jigar,
> 
> I think this is what you are after:
> 
> http://crawler.archive.org/apidocs/org/archive/crawler/url/canonicalize/package-summary.html
> 
> You can download the Heritrix source code and extract what you need 
> (adhering to the LGPL license of course).

Yes, those are the configurable 'canonicalization' settings. These 
affect what URI is considered to have been 'included'. That is, though 
URI N is scheduled, it is actually URI C = canonicalize(N) that is 
considered to have been scheduled. So all future URIs that also 
canonicalize to C are considered redundant.

There is another kind of normalization which we do, inside the 
UURIFactory/UURI classes -- see the package:

  http://crawler.archive.org/apidocs/org/archive/net/package-summary.html

These perform URI transformations that are mandatory or practically 
necessary to generate a fetchable URI, following the behavior of popular 
web browsers as much as possible. (UURI is an abbreviation for "Usable 
URI".)

This UURI normalization always happens, and happens *before* 
canonicalization.

So in fact if the URI originally discovered is O, it is first 
UURI-normalized...

    N = uuri-normalize(O)

...and this N version is what will actually be scheduled/fetched. This N 
version is further canonicalized...

   C = canonicalize(N)

...for already-seen testing/tracking. Any future URIs that also 
normalize-canonicalize down to C will typically be skipped as already-seen.

Hope this helps,

- Gordon @ IA
